moves.1. e4 c5: i usually play sicilian against e4
moves.2. Nf3 d6: continuing book moves for sicilian opening
moves.3. Bc4: white appears to be looking for the "fried liver" attack...
moves.3... Nf6: and if white plays Ng5, e6 will stop whites plans
moves.4. Nc3 Nc6 5. O-O g6 6. Ng5: and white goes for the Ng5...
moves.9. Nf3 a6: a6 stops any thoughts of white playing Bb5
moves.10. Re1: white attempts to gain control of the center and push his e4 pawn
moves.10... Nh7: with h7 open black positions his knight to start an attack on whites kingside
moves.11. Rb1: white following his book plan moves his rook off the long diagonal
moves.11... Ng5: black continues his plan to attack the kingside and if white takes the g5 knight blacks h file opens for his rook and queen to assault whites queen
moves.12. Bxg5: white wishes to keep his knight on f3 captures with his bishop and black opens the h file as planned
moves.12... hxg5 13. Kh1: Kh1 to give space for his f3 knight after blacks pawn push to g4
moves.13... g4 14. Ng1: and black's plans are cooking ... the rook sac at h2 opens up whites kingside
moves.16. Nh3: white is forced to play Ng3
moves.16... Be5+ 17. Kg1 gxh3 18. gxh3: gxh3 allows Qxh3 hemming in whites King
moves.18... Qxh3 19. f3: opening up f file for Bishop check and subsequent mate
